titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Kupferstichkabinett 78 D 8 (olim Hamilton 337) Annotations

div.note: Holtus ("Considerazioni") published lines 1-109; his edition is a diplomatic one (45-48), with abbreviations reproduced and word divisions as in the manuscript. Tobler published lines 1-111 (pp. 617-19); he reproduces the text without punctuation other than the final periods and the lines that mark caesura here at the beginning of the poem, and without distinguishing u/v.
MS: une (final -e is expunctuated)
MS: quilens with a dot under each letter, "il" i"; emend to queus

Tobler omits the superscript after ".iiii."; Holtus seems to have a small "m" over the roman numeral. This MS abbreviation appears only with ".iiii." (six times) and would seem to be validated by line 6271, when in a prayer Christ arose after 4 days; and in line 11057, where four men are chosen as electors for the king to replace Charles Martel, and listed immediately thereafter. Furthermore, the "m" in lines 9334 and 11496 has no final upstroke.
End of Holtus's diplomatic transcription.
End of Tobler's edited selection.
All text that is written above the line in the original is enclosed in parentheses in this transcription.
This line is problematic for sense; the Turin version is also unclear.
MS: neis. We are understanding as "n'es," the pronouns (es= (the) same); cf. Turin line 215, "così è"
MS: revser
MS: nolōs. This is an interesting slip: non added to a form of voloir.
For the forms glese, glesse, glesie, see Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 341).
MS: ia belist. belist is a hapax. Elsewhere in the text, we find l'abelist, e.g., 4169, 6321, etc.
There is a "+" in the right margin in light brown ink, perhas inserted by a nineteenth-century reader.
Cf. Entrée d'Espagne, gaumenter (TL gaimenter), but also 9746 here, gamenta de soit, 'he complained of thirst,' and note.
MS missing an abbreviation mark here in acoplir; cf. Vv. 1271, 1282, etc.
The MS is difficult to read: 'r'of complira is unclear.
pregant: the "g" has an unusual form; it looks more like a "y"

MS: empial. Cf. vv. 47, 73, 373, etc., where we see emp[er]ial. However, see empir in the Prise de Pampelune (v. 4970) and the many other variants. As one of the most frequent words in epic vocabulary, it is greatly varied in rhyme. Furthermore, in Italian, "empio" means "irreligioso, sacrilego, profanatore" and "spietato, crudele" (Zingarelli) so while there is the hint of emperor, there is also the sense of merciless, sacrilegious ruler.
MS: abosdivoir. Cf. Entrée d'Espagne: bosdeor; Guerra d'Attila: bosder, bosdeor, bosdera, bosdie, etc.
MS: confortas ɾoe
Tutore: cf. www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/tuttora_(Enciclopedia-Dantesca)/. Typical of Old Italian, found in Dante, the Fiore, etc. Consulted Nov. 26, 2016.
MS: monreç
Note the Italianate construction of definite article + possessive.
haïr: this could be haïr, anger, but we are interpreting it as "air" to go with the Turin reading and also the sense here: out the window and into the air, the sky.

This laisse is included in Tobler, p. 615. He does not always resolve abbreviations as here, always using "n" for the titulus indicating a nasal. There are no substantial differences in transcription.

la is almost unreadable in the manuscript. It is unclear whether this was intentional or not on the part of the scribe or was done later; it seems to be something painted over those letters, but similar to a spot on the left side of the page of a chocolate or cafeaulait color.
Catchword at the bottom of the page, almost entirely washed out:si
There are three other forms (aflicions twice, aflicion once), all in rhyme position. Therefore I here presume aflicion as the base form, here elided with the preposition a.
Transcribed by Tobler, lines 1180-1220 (pp. 615-16). We note any substantial differences here. As noted above, his resolution of abbreviations differs; thus, "Par moy" for line 1218, etc.

Between lines 1249 and 1250 in column 9Va, running into the right margin is a line with an "x"; also at the bottom of column 9va, there is a line with a corresponding "x" in the left margin. Since the column is one line too long in comparison to the other, and normally the columns are equal, this final line (1264) is clearly to be moved to the position between 1249 and 1250.
This laisse is also transcribed by Tobler (pp. 616-17); again we note any substantial differences of transcription.

This line is problematic; we are interpreting as a separated future (ti ho dire = ti dirò). T has difficulties with it as well, with a substantial difference in reading: line 1287 Se zò mantene ch[e] tu ai dito i[n] to s[er]mone, ("If you continue that which you have said in your speech"); cf. diroy (vv. 1246, 1944, 2422, 2448), in rhyme position.
Tobler: uoire / non poit. The MS reads "voie"

"Sir désigne la ville de Tyr, puisque les tissus d'Orient étaient réputés et [...] l'on indique volentiers une ville d'Orient comme lieu d'où provient un tissu précieux" ("Sir" refers to the city Tyre, since oriental fabrics were famous and a famous city of the East is frequently used as a source for a valuable fabric (Vallecalle, trans. LZM)).
MS: ma[n]da na, however it seems most likely to be an error for "via[n]da na"; cf. line 6181 viande n'a.
MS: q eloiaute; an nseems to be elided, which would have read: Q'en loiauté.
chareme: interpreted as "carême," fasting.

The rhyme here is normally a diphthongue but the simple past of oïr is bisyllabic, so the editor must choose between the rhyme spellings or the usual representation of the simple past of this verb. See also 8160, 11274.
In the rhyme position, the verb "savoir" takes this unusual form.
MS: riponse; cf. forms of reponser (v. 2505, 2690, etc.).
MS: constatinople
MS: afie đs (crossed 'd' and long 's' above the line between 'a' and 'f').
trainé here is the infinitive, missing the final -r ; this is how T understood the line. Alternatively it could be v'oit trainé, "the kings had there dragged before them"

MS: S maint de lor soit bien o voir gravois? The MS is damaged at this point and extremely difficult to read. T: morty zasere al sabione [dead men lying on the sand]. If the reading here were similar, it might be hon veit sor ce gravois; but the two are not always parallel. Gravoy appears appears five times, gravois once, meaning "sand" or "gravel" in some way (path, etc.) in this MS.

The beginning of this column is faded in parts, though the outlines of strokes are clear. For multiple minims, there can always be doubts, but in searching other F-I texts there are no forms of sui- for the verb "to follow," whereas there are 68 forms of siv- attested in FIOLA. RIALFrI however, offers both. In this text there are 3 other forms with siv-, one seut, but none with sui- unless the minims are reconstrued in those appearances as well, thus siveç here, though the connectors are in fact suiveç.
guioner: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 346), "guide."
esclaris: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 307), re esclarir and the change of conjugation in Franco-Italian.
MS: giat
MS: nos
enci: cf. Holtus ( Lexicalische p. 290), "ici," 'here.'
The word et seems out of place here; emend to e? Cf. T line 1911, Homo sonto de Carlo Martelo ...

Between les and afi at the end of the line is a hole in the MS; afi seems to be written deliberately after it; there does not seem to be any letter missing. J.-C. Vallecalle suggests that it might have been an a there [possibly scraped off?], making the line read Posible çonse il fust, bien le sai a fi, that is, "This [Huon's mission in Hell] would be possible, I know certainly (... if Hell were built on earth)."
gieter may have been the original reading of the text, for "how to shoot a bow".
MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for n:m'acontent; cf. V. 747
T 2126: Se p[er] devin miraclo non m'avene
These 6 lines are very difficult to read due to the ink being worn off. Ultraviolet does not help much.
aquitier: there are 16 forms beginning with aquit- (and one other following d') compared to 9 that are clearly quit-, so we have divided those following d as beginning with the vowel.
MS: resont with a caret below to insert a tiny p written above the line.
MS: le nay ster
n and u are frequently very similar in the MS. Ansi is perhaps also possible or intended.
MS: Bout
For the construction in genoillon, see Holtus (Lexicalische pp. 338-39).
galon: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische p. 334), "côté," 'side.'
âbandon="a abandon"
Veriteç appears twice (5504, 11099) and veritere once (6308) to one verté (8736), so we resolve here as we do.

aveit a bone foyseems to be a MS error with either an extraa(he had good faith or he went in good faith) or perhaps a u for an n (aneit as some form of "andare"), though there is no such form listed in RIALFrI for other Franco-Italian texts.
noç: Final letter is hard to distinguish; could be os.
The phrase sans poy appears to be equivalent to "sans plus"; could it be an Italianism, with palatalization of the consonant + l (cf. Modern Italian "più")?
We believe thatsavra is like the use of Modern Standard Italian "sapere," "to taste": it seems (it tastes) like...
Compare T, line 2484: grande e derupossa p[er]ché ponto son li agradise

Brown ink through theor of d[e]morr[re]. mal has a line above it; it is not the standard abbreviation for r or vowel + r, and there are no other abbreviations with l, so its resolution is not immediately evident.
MS: sta[n]cht
Compare T, line 2542: Quando e∙l vede avrire la gola ch'el vede el fogo apredre; B seems to be understanding vait for both verbs, baër and esprenda[n]t

T has understood this differently, line 2584: "I praise [him] willingly (with good heart)." This could also be the meaning here, in which case the preceding line would end with a comma instead of a semicolon.
M: lö tēptz. This seems to be an unusual case of assonance alone, not rhyme.
After tost, scratched out letter in the MS.
There is a letter scratched out after il before atant. This folio in general has many corrections.
si stoit: they had to, they needed to; cf. T 2665, Quando lo zorno li mancha se ly coventa albergare

li jorner: This expression can mean "journey" or "day" in Old French. In Italian, it might have that meaning (DELI, 13th century), but "day" is the first and more frequent meaning. It is difficult to say which is intended here.
ge inserted above the line.

Stengel's review of Brockstedt includes this laisse. He uses square brackets for additions, parentheses for things he believes should be omitted. Included here are lines where he does either. Not noted are differences in uses of written accents.
Stengel (Review): ce q(e)'armés
Stengel (Review): [e]n est

Note the use of n here for "nous" (ne before vowel) object form. This is typical of early Italian texts. See Rohlfs, Morfologia, paragraph 460. This is a legal formula meaning in the presence of witnesses.
Stengel (Review): Qu(e)'aveque
Stengel (Review): E [va]
Stengel (Review): (por)forma
MS: Lort; the final letter seems to be an anticipation of the following word's final letter. T: Alora se ne vene al maro [...]
End of the selection transcribed in Stengel's review.
MS: ci ņait. Though the n is expunctuated, it seems to be necessary for the meaning; see translation.
MS: vos vos pri ne mie: second vos and ne are expunctuated.
MS: pelle. p with a line above is always p[re] and thus is so transcribed here.
Abbreviation line very light in the MS.
MS: vait.seems to be a form of "valoir"
MS: alieç: CF T-L 278-279 alegier, "to be eased, lightened"; Folco di Candia> V19, l. 1581.
Thse laisse initial here has a face sketched into it.
We interpret aseori as from *asseoir, "to rest, stop on a trip."
quoy=coi="tranquille," T-L "still"; s'ora derives from orer "anwünschen"="wish"
dela : "over there," not "by there," so one word. There are many appearances of this construction in rhyme position.
MS: mont le sen: le expunctuated
segure: DELI scure, segure before 1292, derives from SECŪRE(M), Latin
Funny face drawn into the capital for this laisse, as for many in this section of the MS.
This version differs from Turin where it is the serpent that cries out.

Or va pur a giter. This is one case where the French and Italian constructions differ but the meaning is approximately the same: "by rolling he was going to move it" and "by rolling he was going to toss it."

For this section, cf. Le roman d'Alexandre, Branche III, laisses 160-162, part of the "Dangerous Valley" where Alexander confronts a demon in order to leave. (Harf-Lancner trans. of E. C. Armstrong, pp. 470-477).
Here Huon addresses the figure aloud.
The MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for an "r" here: archiere, "archer," as in vv. 1710, 9216, 11662, 1204 archiers
This might be a reference to Dante's hell: those inside the walls of Hell (Canto 10) cannot see the present and see the future only dimly (10.94-105).
MS: oi ge, with ge expunctuated, the g with a dot above, the e with dot both above and below.
MS: lemme
Emendation for MS nōs avōs; note the use of the first person plural as subject.
MS: geste beste

The grammatical structure here is unclear; this is the only sere form in the text. The people (or their spokesperson) are using "tu" with Huon, so it seems unlike that this is "seré" = 'by us you will be honored'; perhaps this is the "tu" form. On the other hand, using a conjugated verb after a preposition is also unlikely; see Turin, "mostra-ne la via p[er]ché seremo tuty salve", 'show us the way so that we will all be saved', where the conjunction is used. Thus we have left the line as is.
Cf. Turin, line 3704: quando y[n] mia vita tanto ben fato averò
si seiron could also read s'iseiron, "they went out"; there are no similar forms for "to sit," and Turin has them sitting down, "putting" themselves at the table.
alor could also read a lor, "to them." Cf. T 3801 a le soue done
MS: vons
MS: el (inserted above the line)
T, line 4079: De zorno y[n] zorno quanty y[n] naserano (line 4079); it would seem that the Italian writer did not understand the text.
MS: fable pece home
This is Psalm 133, verses 1-2; Dante also quotes it in his Monarchia, Book 1.
The following line (4212) in T reads, "con più marinary chi menauna grosa nava
te[re]rre: This is unusual, perhaps the adding of an unnecessary abbreviation mark when the full word is already present.

Cf. Matthew 7.14, "For the gate is narrow and the way is hard, that leads to life, and those who find it are few." Vulgate: "Quam angusta porta, et arcta via est, que ducit ad vitam: et pauci sunt qui inveniunt eam!" If we were to transcribe Stroite ert la voie qui no l'atient a tant it would reflect an Italianate structure with a tanti: "Stretta è la via che non l'ottiene a tanti" or "non la tiene a tanti"– "that not many can hold to it' "or "that not many can succeed at it"
This is a complicated passage, with non-standard forms: aroman in particular poses a riddle.

Meregazzi ("L'Episodio") includes from here these laisses 164-174, line 4664. She uses a capital letter only for new sentences, not at the beginning of each line, and does not note resolution of abbreviations. Any substantial difference in transcription (i.e., not capitals, her resolutions or her standard word division) will be noted. She does not use quotation marks here, so direct conversation is not evident, though she does later in the passage transcribed.
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): ata[c]ha
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): comenciet le jor
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qui l'ont
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): oille istrent
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): le menton
The first hemistich of this line seems to be a repeat of 4501 above; in Turin, however, the two also repeat. so it is clearly part of the tradition.

charene: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 251), "cherene: affection"; he cites also Gui de Nanteuil "carine," so we see to have a combination of the two here (cf. also Matsumura, "cherine," citing Entrée d'Espagne). But the word also appears in line 1560; between the two, it seems here to mean "penitence," and in fact, Turin reads "gran quaresema fay, ancha no[n] vite la simele" (line 4461), with "Lent" as the original derivation.
flagelle: Cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 326), "flageller, fouetter," 'to whip.'
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): dapne elle
It is unclear whether this line belongs to Huon or to Prester John. Meregazzi interprets it as being Prester John who says it; we include it as part of Huon's response.

Istrent, istront appear a number of times in this text; aman this once, but also in Attila, where it is defined as "subito" IX, 254. T clearly did not understand: li stre[n]ze la man, "he shook his hand."
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): por ice
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): un quartier de pem

Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): ostalaisent; there does not seem to be any record of a similar verb, more likely ostà (past participle of "oster" or "ost[el]er") + a form of the verb laisser = well-lodged. Cf. Turin line 4524.
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): n'a nil de voir

MS : adonet; the e cross-stroke is very light but present. Since the scribe is in general very careful expunctuating errors and otherwise correcting, this seems to be a true error and we here emend. Meregazzi: adonct

Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): feroi ge. Her word division does not alter the meaning, the verb remains present conditional, first person; the ending is frequently -oige for that form (see Mainone, Formen, pp. 15-17; Laut, p. 49).
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): mille visque, mant en la sor. However there are no forms "visque" in the MS, and frequently "jusque" (with its abbreviations) has a similar form.
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qu'il vit
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): pam bescuit; she also notes, "corr. anone in avoine"
asié comes from aasier (TL), "to reassure."
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qu'il en gardast
Meregazzi ("L'Episodio") stops here to pick up again later.
Tobler transcribes lines 4665-4672 (p. 619).
Stengel includes this section in his "Eine weitere Textstelle," numbering it 4669-5008.

The end of the line could also be interpreted fai ces demostreison, but since Turin reads "fazy demostranza" we construe it this way. There are no other forms faicés; faige and faigés are related to "fatigué," but there are three faice tokens from "to do/to make."
Stengel ("Eine weitere"): dau [sien] consoil
Catchword after this line: A Ynide

The previous line, at the end of folio 32V, ends with the catchwords A Ynide which do not then begin the next folio or signature. There is a space in the MS after arcives that seems to be scraped; something is visible around the edges. With ultraviolet, one can almost see "q" and "e", and maybe something above the line too, qe with u above the line? Or just a bit of chalk solution or whatever they used.Thus we give this as an emendation. Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 39): L'Arcives[ch]
MS: plais

The reading Tholomé here is problematic, since Tholomeus has not been designated head of the band of ambassadors or otherwise much discussed until now. MS T, line 4745, reads "Servire debe esere tal sire [et] de grande [et] de menore"; perhaps the original here was "tal ome" (such a man), referring to the king, perhaps referring to the king. There are two possible avenues for distraction, the first written, and the second oral. In the first column of this folio, in line four (this is line 3 of column two) in line 4707, "Tholomeu" appears, so could have distracted a copyist. If the scribe were writing under dictation, he might have thought he heard"tol ome" instead of "tel ome," and would have added the "h" after the "t" because he had just encountered the name earlier [with thanks to colleagues for confirmation].
Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 41): fil econtre
The end of this line and the next are missing in the MS.
MS: selong
MS: peçe=OF "pieça"; Stengel ("Eine weitere"): Lle
MS indeed reads bein
Langlois lists Teris as Lord of Vermandois (p. 668).
This line is incomplete in the MS. These laisses are not in B, so there can be no reconstruction from that text.
MS: un êve since êve is always feminine in this text="une eve"
MS: pote[r] for 'porter,' the gate-keeper.
Something is clearly missing in this line, perhaps de [servir] vos? Cf. T, line 4782, "de complire la vostra volontady"

This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4820 reads "Ay, cristianità, como ay tuo onore p[er]duto!" There is a letter after m that was removed, it looks like another m; the rest of the letters are bled through from the back.
End of Stengel's "Eine weitere" transcription.

This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4851 reads "Dona," dize Berardo, "che loro lasate-ly y[n]trare". There is clearly a difficulty with this line, though the general idea is clear: "Lady," said Berardo,"may you allow them to enter."
MS: jambaseors
MS: colleste
Unusual abbreviation form: empeos with a sign over e and o-; perhaps a two-part sign?
MS: serees; the second e has a tiny dot below and a bigger one above; not clear though if it should be expunctuated. We have done so here.

The capital here is unusual in that it is not decorated at all with filigrees. Normally the red capitals are decorated with purplish designs and the blue with red; here the capital is bare and simple.
MS T, line 4955 reads: "vuy avite p[er] vuy tramiso, [et] zò e my y[n]seme siemo." ensoine : cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, pp. 300-301), "scusa," 'excuse.'
cu[m]: the final "n" here is the "vertical m" found in Latin texts. Cf. CPLEDTM, Fasc. 1, p. 28.
We understand strine related to the verb "stringere."
For the construction with irer, see Holtus (Lexicalische, pp. 352-53).
MS: ētase

MS: avon. MS T, lines 5179-80 read: "che avante m'averoy lo coro fenduto / e l'anyma de my del tuto avere p[er]duta" [...for I would first have my heart split, and my soul completely lost (i.e., be dead) before I would...]
fortese: Cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 329), "force."
MS T, line 5212: "chi non fosse y[n] vergogna de l'apele" [who is not ashamed to call him]

trasumans: cf. Dante Par. 1, 70. This must be one of its earliest usages after Dante (DELI: before 1321, Dante, first use). The final word, desuor, is problematic; we render as "u" the two downstrokes that are linked both above and below. There is no equivalent in other MSS; the meaning seems to be that he had passed beyond and is now no longer present.
MS: baroine. The second and third strokes are clearly linked at the top and the first and second at the bottom.

MS: sa aubçēt ("b" also has a titulus over it). We emend here in part because of syllable count and in part because of sense: "sa aubercent" does not make sense: it is either two verbs together or a singular possessive pronoun plus plural verb.
reïre: from the prefix RE- + ire

Should this be "Canace" from Ovid's Heroides 11, where she committed incest with Macareus, her brother, and her father Aeolus sent her a sword to kill herself (and exposed the baby)? In 1542 it was made into a play by Sperone Speroni, so was clearly known in Italy in the sixteenth century. For the English translation, see http://www.poetryintranslation.com/PITBR/Latin/Heroides8-15.php#anchor_Toc524696648.
MS appears to read niiēs

The forms here are unlike others we have seen in this text; and these lines are omitted from the T MS. We have interpreted sorer as "suer" and scaulir as "echauffer" through an Italianate "caldo" since Ital "scaldare"=to burn, though one might expect opposite expressions. The T text (in a different order) does mention the 'fire of love,' v. 5346, "Lo feu d'amore sovente li fate sentire." Holtus (Lexicalische, pp. 454-55), relates it to "essorer," with varying meanings according to the text; 'to relax, cool off.'
MS: pālam
MS: dolonor
MS: empëo, where the descender of the p is also crossed
MS: susnel
gaberisse: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 333), "raillerie," 'mockery, scoffing.'
The identity of "Sulliendre" is unclear; there is no record of the name in that form in Classical or medieval literature. The references are missing from the T MS.
For Porus, see the Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 30-240.
The meaning and derivation of desgrendre are unclear. Perhaps "sgrenre"? For the form, cf. genero=gendre; tenero=tendre etc.'to seed a fruit/remove bits from cob; recite the rosary; eat with glee'

Disticha catonis Catonis distichorum 30: Quae culpare soles, ea tu ne feceris ipse, Turpe est doctori, cum culpa redarguit ipsum. [Those things you are accustomed to blame do not do yourself; It is bad for a wise man when his own guilt comes back (to haunt him)]. Text and translation, Jim Marchand, http://faculty.georgetown.edu/jod/texts/distich.trans.html.
MS: mebruç
For the form se lagne, see Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 358).
esmatés: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 311), "terrasser, détruire," 'to crush, destroy.'
MS: dorit
baster:=Italian "bastare" [to be enough, to suffice]; attested 1253, DELI (unknown origin; no attestation in OF, TL)

avist: there are three tokens with this sequence of letters: 5601 and 7579 in addition to this line. In each case it is a form of the verb "to have," interpreted also by Mainone as avist (Formenlehre 24), similar to the forms in Entrée d'Espagne, Attila, V4, etc. As Veillard and Guyotjeannin's Conseils suggest, the alternation between "u" and "v" (avit and avait appear, as do aüst and aüstes, aüsés) suggests an interpretation with "v" (Fasc. I, 25).
MS: maçerie: the letter l seems to have been corrected in r (for "Margery").
MS: nuit demi .pl'. with a caret between nuit and demi
Tobler transcribes from here through line 6139 (pp. 607-609).
Blank folio, Recto and Verso, follows.
Meregazzi, "Prete Gianni" picks up her transcription here, her lines 6223-6552, here 6068-6397.
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 32): n'en cuit
Tobler: de grant pri . [sic]. The print seems to be missing a letter at the end.
MS: mai/s; an "s" seems to be written over an "i"; Tobler: mas; Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 34): m'as
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 34): Si non
avenois: see Holtus (Lexicalische p. 224).
End of Tobler transcribed section.
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 36): fors qui l'en dure
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 38) includes only the final line as a quote.
plus mes: "plus mieux"
MS: son son signor
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 40): Lors que
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 40): qi conquis

golir: an Italian-based form; cf. Guerra d'Attila, goloient; TLIO goliare, "desiderare"
MS: (t) is inserted above line with a caret under the line before the s is underpunctuated at end of the word.

Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 50): aré tinir. There are no forms "aré" or "tinir" in this text; "tenir" appears 25 times (5 with [n]). "retenir" in various conjugated forms appears numerous times, including "retint." Turin line 6050 read "retenire" in line-final position. The "a-" prefix is frequent in Franco-Italian, as noted above.
In the manuscript, the final stroke of the –r is missing, perhaps worn away.
Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 52): acrement
End of Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni").

Stengel publishes from here to line 6992. He notes in the introduction that he edits for reading ease: resolving abbreviations, differentiating i/j and u/v and adding punctuation. Any comments related to that edition will be listed by Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe"). Differences in editing style are not noted.
mesay: TL meshaigne=mahaigne=mehaigne, "damage"

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 687): qu'il conseut (with no explanation); MS: cōsent, very clear, but of course confusion between links for minims is quite possible. Quant que: quando che is a veneto expression according to Zingarelli 2018, for "quando, proprio quando"
s'aregone: Cf. T, line 6108 "s'araduna," to meet; we are interpreting "aregone" as related to aringo TLIO , "a place for meeting, a meeting" and extrapolate the verb as "to meet"
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 688): (!) At the end of the line
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 689): "Que ferés ...
car: Italianate form, "cher" for 'noble'
fanos written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for object pronouns following the imperative.
astu written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for subject following the verb in question.
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 690): Venuç [a] li
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 690): enfer atrover
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 691): luy [g]e
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 691): Conten[t]eç moy
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): de ci
engaigne: trickery, cunning, wiliness

Mestre could be understood as a feminine plural here, in which case the comparison would be with other female necromancers. The line in general is tricky because the verb seems singular (soit) but tant would indicate a plural.

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692) : efforç par. Cf. the Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 207-213, seeking the trees of the Sun and the Moon (ed. Harf-Lancner pp. 528-535). All references to the Alexandre will be to this edition and the format Branch, laisse(s) or verse(s).
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): Et qui distrent
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): au roy (!) pooire; Roman d'Alexandre, Porus I, laisse 217, etc. for Porus.
Alexandre, l. 3189

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): qui [tant]ert
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): Qu'ici. There are 15 appearances of "ici" versus 140 of "ci" so we have divided differently.
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): et la dame en demin (emend)
We are presuming a missing "a" after "plaise" for a parallel construction with line 6573.

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 694): a la vetre maison
I [n]ombre: there is clearly an abbreviation line over the i but it does not seem to make sense here– perhaps the scribe made an error at the beginning of a column. T has no n.
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 695): Apalpe nos; since the rest of the discourse is in the second person plural, we presume this is too and accent the final syllable.

Jâ = Ja a
Viscardi (Letteratura franco-italiana, pp. 133-34) includes through line 6636.

li lusage: this seems to be a case of "concretion of the article": that is, lusage is a plural noun for "habits" or "customs." Cf. Rohlfs ¶341, l. 3189, followed by . Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 696), followed by Viscardi: si l'usage; the MS reads clearly "li"
sorvage: TL: sorvenir, hinzukommen, 'to ensue'; Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 696): so(r)vage
Note the use of verbs of appearing or seeming rather than being.

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 697): est açe; the letters are all written together, not separated. Though OF might suggest pillars, T understood "rooms" (stanzie, v. 6338). The form also suggests an equivalence with "estage," which might mean residences (cf. T-L: rooms; residences).
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 697): il [i] vont
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 697): reguardant
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 698): le charoill(e)

Long epic comparison beginning here: victor after a tourney and his arrival. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 698): ant .II. grant (beginning of line missing); Viscardi (Letteratura franco-italiana, p. 135), includes the entire laisse based on Stengel.
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 698): gaaign[é]
Viscardi: puign

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe"): Yesu! MS: yhu, with abbreviation line over the "h." Throughout, "Yesu" is Stengel's resolution of this abbreviation.
E·maintes = "En maintes"
(e): written above the line, very light, no caret below (not visible in the microfilm). DELI: vanagloriarsi "vantarsi, essere pieno di sé," 13th century.
MS: Mes e non: ..: expunctuated 'e' after the first word

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): l'estriver. This is the only appearance of the expression in the text, and "le" is written slightly apart from the following word; see introduction on vowel + s + consonant. Cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, pp. 319-20), "étrier," "stirrup."

Matthew 27, 46; Mark 5, 34

MS, Stengel: l'asist. This does not make sense, since the queen approaches him then speaks to him. Cf. Turin line 6448 "dapresso luy s'aseta e possa li rasona"; it can be a banal error of misreading a written text to confuse "l" and the long "s"
Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): ne l'[av]oit

Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): devers, which normally means "in the direction of"; "de devers" would mean from the area of ("du côté de," Matsumura). Thus two words here, as they are in the MS.

(qe) inserted above the line with caret below, but very light with tiny letters, not visible in microfilm.

Sections of these three lines of the MS are here practically unreadable since somewhat rubbed off; as the middle of the section, the beginning of this line in particular is difficult to distinguish. Whether it is vos or ves cannot be determined.

Begin Stengel, "Suche" (his line 7148). He uses square brackets for his emendations/additions, and parentheses for his items to remove. He seeks to regularize the lines to 10 or 12 syllables, usually in comparison with the Turin version and Andrea da Barberino.
aneslepas: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 292): "eneilepais," "immédiatement."
FEW: talevas, "bouclier en bois"; cf. Roman d'Alexandre "talavat/z" (RIALFrI, 22.XII.2017), from *TALAPACIUM (https://apps.atilf.fr/lecteurFEW/lire/131/35)
Stengel ("Huons Suche," p.1): Pou(t)

(t): inserted above the line, with a dim caret below.
c(h)ar: very light insert, with no caret below.

See illumination below; on left, ship with line tied to horse; on right, Huon fighting off the birds. Lots of blood, some birds in air, some on ground, and flock coming toward him. Cf. Roman d'Alexander again, for attacks near a pond (Branche 3, laisses 64-85) that include griffons that carry away horses (3, 66; Harf-Lancner pp. 368-87, esp. 370-71).
Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): b[er] natural

See illumination below: merpeople, male and female. Possible source: there are a number of similar monsters in the Roman d'Alexandre, 3, 164 (for mermaids); for men in two parts above the navel, 3, 181, etc.

As Meregazzi says ("Ugo," 19), the Roman d'Alexandre cites "li Otifal" (p. 319, l. 19, ed. Michelant), so we have divided this into Roman d'Alexandre cites "li Otifal" (p. 319, l. 19, ed. Michelant), so we have divided this into L'Ocifal. However, Harf-Larcner uses "Liotifal" (III, 2452) for "Ichtyophages"; grammatically, an article seems to be necessary in both the Alexandre and here.

Possibly this could be d'amere, "of loving"; however, it lacks a pronoun as a referrent. See also the various references in Dante's Comedy to Virgil as parent: Inf. 23.38, for instance. Furthermore, the Turin version reads "d'amare."

MS: perice. "peris"="de pierre" (EE, GdA), but in 1355-56, the pope says that there is wood in it. Also, this adjective would not normally precede a noun.
Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): dentrel(e)

soie might be here the feminine possessive adjective, possibly in an Italianate construction. This would be the only time in the text the form would appear after the noun. It could also be s'oie: "he also had [held] the entire time." The three lines 7701-7703 refer to the episode in the illumination at the bottom of the page, where burning masses fall into water, and spirits are led along the side of the stream. T 7383 reads, "Vite un monte che tuto se corla e tuto brusa" for 7702; there is no equivalent to 7701. Perhaps it means "He called on God, Holding the cross in his hand the whole time." In line 7702, the word "sevre" or "seure" could rather be "essever," "esseu" as drain, channel, ditch from "to stream out, flow away" (similar to English sewer).

T 7442: "Ora me dite," dize lo [con]te, "a ponto a ponto, no[n] me celate: Turin has two forms of the verb "to say." Here we seem have "Ore m'oÿ," "Now listen to me" in order to keep the syllable count. The verb form however would be second person singular, not plural as at the end of the line.

enclostre: clearly written together in the MS. This is a Franco-Italianism, by someone very conscious of language structures. It derives from énkāuston; as DELI points out, the -l- was inserted. However, one must also note that Latin -CL- (/kl/), like other consonants before -L- is normally palatalized in Italian (Rohlfs ¶¶¶ 247-248; 250; 270), the spelling -clo- may represent a false etymology on the part of a scribe.

This line is missing from T. The first hemistich is problematic; it is grammatical, but knowing how to fish and not getting anything though they know how is a little strange. Perhaps it was something with "avoir à" originally; "A pescher s'avomes," "We must fish" [...]. "se" as pronoun for the first person plural is well-documented (see Wünderli, "Se omnipersonnel dans L'Aquilon de Bavière"). Rohlfs (¶702) gives examples of "avere" with an infinitive without a preposition, but it is unclear to him and also from the examples whether an "a" is assimilated into either the conjugated verb or the dependent infinitive. He notes that in northern Italy various verbs are used with infinitive meaning "dovere," but gives no examples with "avere." Since the hemistich does make grammatical sense as it stands we have not separated a pronoun from the verb, but suggest this alternative meaning.

M. Scattonlini edits from this line through 10382 in her dissertation. She has generously allowed us to compare readings, sharing her transcription with us. Where we differ in reading, it will be noted. She does not use capitals at the beginning of each line, or diereses, and the punctuation differs; these we do not note. In addition her word divisions can differ. She also resolves all abbreviations for "p" with per, where we vary according to context. The copy that we have is electronic, and therefore we do not give page numbers; the line numbers should suffice, though she uses Stengel's line numbers for the Berlin version.

afaitement: see Bezzola, Storia dei gallicismi (253). ; while OF afaitement has the standard definition of arrangement, appearance, or construction (cf. Matsumura, T-L), or a collection of graceful qualities (DEAF-él), Italian also has the sense of "enchanted thing"; cf. DELI for affatturare, 'to put under a spell; to alter, falsify'/counterfit" already in the fourteenth century (before Dante). This seems to be the sense here, 'magical creation/origin.' See also lines 10819, 10944.

Tobler: ɾaincte Marie. Forms of "Marie" with the saint prefix appear 19 times; of those, 6 are abbreviated. Of the remaining 13, 11 are "sancte" with only 2 "saincte," so we here follow the most frequent, though overall "sainct/e" forms are more frequent (93 to 52, including adjectives, superlatives, verb). In line 9032 below, two unabbreviated forms "saincte vie" appear, so we resolve to follow those.
a conduir: separated future, "will lead," typical of the northern Italian peninsula (see Rohlfs, vol. 2, Morfologia, ¶ 590).

See illumination at the bottom of the page for the four gates; they would seem, however, to be out of order. The one to the right seems to have its gates on the ground, with a figure of a man above; the third from the binding seems to have a lion above. Note the three men to the left; Aeneas, Guillaume d'Orange, and Huon. Huon seems to either have a brown face here, or be wearing a mask. All three are identifiable through their clothes as seen in the earlier three illuminations..

This quote (or paraphrase) would seem to be related to classical condemnations of hubris, such as that of Hesiod in his Theogony (where he relates the succession of gods getting what is coming to them in return for assaulting authority), and in particular his Works and Days, where he illustrates how hard work merits an appropriate reward, in opposition to the hubris for glorious deeds advocated by the classical epics of Homer. He especially praises Justice, Zeus's favorite daughter. See http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0132%3Acard%3D1 for the translation into English (esp. chapters 255-73 for Justice).

MS: ceran; this word does not seem to appear in any dictionary, but the MS reading is clear; it would seem to mean either a place or a time. Terran, terren, etc. appears numerous times in this text, and in other F-I texts both as noun and adjective; in RIALFRI on 9 Nov. 2018, teran appears 19 times, frequently in rhyme, and "c" and "t" confusions are frequent in paleographical tradition.

Cf. Dante, Inf. 2.13; according to tradition, Aeneas had a son after his death, whom his wife bore in the woods, so named him "Silvius." Various Latin historians give "Aeneas Silvius" as the son of Silvius (Livy, Ab urbe conditor 1.3; Dionysius of Helicarnassus, Antiquitates romanae 1.71); according to the same historians, his successor was Latinus Silvius. In any case, the descendants of the rulers of the Trojan settlement took the cognomen "Silvius" attached to personal names. Here then the "Silvian" seems to refer to the family line initiated by Aeneas's father, Anchises, whom Aeneas brought with him away from Troy. The father did not make it to the Italian peninsula. Scattolini notes that the reference is backwords and turned around though refering to Inf. (361 n641).

This is the first part of the illumination at the bottom of the page. Several figures are in water up to the waist, with devils at the bottom, rocks over head. The furthest right figure in the swamp has an 'S' over his head. In the middle are the two figures, Huon and Guillaume (who is always identified with a halo, and is in bare feet). Huon is turned toward the left, to Saudin.

For robist see Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 431) and Mainone (Laut und Form, p. 30); fagon is more problematic; see Attila, "facion: .... fazione, l'insieme di schiere di soldati." Mainone is unclear as to the meaning; he originally suggests robist as deriving from a verb form, but being the adjective "wild" [Fr. "rubeste," Ital "rubesto"], each of the sinners in the mud ( he suggests "fagon" is like "fango," "mud," in T and P). Holtus also designates robist as an adjective. ; for fagon, Attila, "facion: .... fazione, l'insieme di schiere di soldati." Mainone is unclear as to the meaning; he originally suggests robist as deriving from a verb form, but being the adjective "wild" [Fr. "rubeste," Ital "rubesto"] each of them in the mud (he suggests "fagon" is like "fango," "mud," in T and P). Holtus also designates it an adjective, "sauvage, violent," [wild, violent] but does not clarify fagons, which does not appear in any other F-I text listed in RIALFRI (as of 6 Dec. 2018).

The illumination at the bottom of this page is of a city with five towers visible, a figure in red (with head covering) at the top of the first gate on the left, nearest the three visitors who are at the far left. The gate figure holds a book with black dots to represent writing on it. Note that the tower is square, suggesting that "reont" refers to something else. Charere (line 9915) means both "chair" (cattedra in MSI) and "highway" in this text, as confirmed by other Franco-Italian texts. In fact, the gateway is rounded and the human figure is at the highest point. Since this is a scholar with a book, it makes the most sense for him to be in a chair or seat. The portion remaining in the Turin MS (folio 146R) shows a loggia with rounded openings to the left of the illumination, with the three travellers outside to the left. One figure inside (with a fancy headdress) is on a chair with a baldacchino in a polygonal shape (not quite a circle, but circular) above. Since the walls in the Berlin MS illumination reach outside the frame, there is nothing above the figure who is on top of the gate there. It is unclear therefore whether the Turin version is a variation of meaning, but in any case, it is one possible explanation of reont.

The illumination at the bottom of this page is of a city with five towers visible, a figure in red (with head covering) at the top of the first gate on the left, nearest the three visitors who are at the far left. The gate figure holds a book with black dots to represent writing on it. Note that the tower is square, suggesting that reont refers to something else. Charere (line 9915) means both "chair" ("cattedra" in MSI) and "highway" in this text, as confirmed by other Franco-Italian texts. In fact, the gateway is rounded and the human figure is at the highest point. Since this is a scholar with a book, it makes the most sense for him to be in a chair or seat. The portion remaining in the Turin MS (folio 146R) shows a loggia with rounded openings to the left of the illumination, with the three travellers outside to the left. One figure inside (with a fancy headdress) is on a chair with a baldacchino in a polygonal shape (not quite a circle, but circular) above. There are several historical figures by the name Nicomachus to whom this may refer. Aristotle's father and son were both so named; the Nichomachean Ethics, a compendium of Aristotle's notes (or Aristotle's notes plus Nichomachus's comments on them) may have been dedicated to the son. Nicomachus of Gerasa, who lived in the first century AD, was a mathematician about whom little is known. His work on the magical properties of numbers and a manual on harmonics, an early discussion of musical theory and pitch. Various other works of his were lost. Since there are references to necromacy in this section, the second identity seems more likely(AEB).
blastemer: for the form, see Holtus (Lexicalische, pp. 325-26).

Farabus: al-Farabi, a great Arabic philosopher, known as Alpharabius in the West, viewed as the "second master" after Aristotle. He lived in the 9th-10th centuries and was known for scientific (which include mathematical and musical works) and philosophical writings (AEB).
See translation for a delineation of speakers in this exchange."

The line is complete, but something is clearly missing for the sense here; cf. T: Dize lo [con]te a Eneas, chy lo mena [The count asks Aeneas, who leads him]. Br similarly reads Dist li quens Ugues ad Eneas qi lo maine (v. 1117).

In this manuscript there are two forms: par poy (2 appearances) and por poy (one appearance), but only por appears with val and its derivatives. Mixed lists are not unknown, so I have resolved thus here.
MS: cu[m] The abbreviation mark here is in the form of a vertical "z"; cf. Viellard, Conseils, Vol. 1, p. 28, # 11.

These are all Saracens from Aspremont: Agolant is the ruler of the Saracens, father of Helmont, and killed by Girard's nephew Claire. Uliens is one of Agolant's judges, an important Saracen in the second half of the poem, killed by Richier, grandson of Duke Berengier.

This does not follow the French version of Aspremont; Roland killed Eaumont (=Helmont=Almonte). There is nothing about Helmont sleeping. See laisses 286-7 in Suard's edition. The sleeping recalls the motif of Roland killing Ferragu in the Entrée d'Espagne, where Ferragu took a nap using a rock as a pillow, and Roland was tempted to kill him with a stone (vv. 3535-3555).

Stengel here proposes the emendation (homes) after .jj. to follow the plot of Aspremont, where Roland kills Eaumont on the second day of the battle. However, jors seems more appropriate for that reason. Cf. F. Suard, ed., Aspremont: Chanson de geste du XIIe siècle, Champion 2008, vv. 3897-5545.
canter has a mark above the 'c', like an apostrophe- meaning unclear, but definitely ink and not a defect in the parchment. T: cercare

"Death by chessboard" is a chanson de geste motif: in the Geste Francor, Ogier the Dane kills Charlot, Charlemagne's son, with a chessboard; in Renaut de Montauban, Bertholet has died thus also, and further incidents appear in the Batârd de Bouillon and in Parise la duchesse, but there is no known incident relating to Thibaut killing his brother-in-law Folco in the East. On chess in the Middle Ages and its uses, see Jenny Adams, Power Play: The Literature and Politics of Chess in the Late Middle Ages, U of Penn P, 2006; Nicholas Perkins, ed., Medieval Romance and Medieval Culture, D. S. Brewer, 2015. An Italian novella, in fact, insists on Thibaut's family relationship to Guillaume through Folco (married to Anfelise, Thibaut's stepsister, niece of Desramé), I Conti di antichi cavalieri, ed. Alberto del Monte Cisalpino-Goliardica, 1972, pp. 118-22.

The illumination at the bottom of this page, 70V, has three parts. Starting at the left, the three men travelling through Hell, Guillaume in front and frontal; Huon to his left and side view; and Aeneas barely visible behind Guillaume's right. In the middle is a lady, side view, in a fancy purple dress with gold decorations; and to the right is a crowned man on a white horse with his sword raised to strike. His trappings are all gold- spurs, saddle, bit.
MS: este followed by expunctuated -e: dots both below and above.
Guilla[u]me: there is an abbreviation apostrophe after the two ll's, so though the name is usually spelled Guillame in the text we have added the u here.

This is the first part of the illumination at the foot of 71R: three men are outside a city wall, within which (center) is a knight without a head covering, but a beard and long haïr, in flames. He wears armor covered by a yellow tunic decorated with black G's.
This is the second part of the illumination on 71R, to the right. Inside the city wall, devils are pushing that same figure (in yellow with black G's) into a cave opening (Hell, one presumes).

Girardo au Fraite [de Vienne] is a chanson de geste character, lord of Burgundy, Milon's brother, father of Rainier, grandfather of Oliver according to the Geste Francor. He revolted against Charlemagne, refusing to aid him in Aspremont. René Louis, De l'histoire à la légende, 3 vols, Imprimerie moderne, 1946-47, proposes various theories about the multiple Girards in chansons de geste.
After laig, letter scratched out; again looks like white-out over the spot.
We are assuming that camperon comes from the verb campare; cf. OF 'eschamper'.

There are no other forms of this as noun or as adjective. However, the suffix -borg does appear, where -urg does not. "The Burgundian" is Girard, lord of Vienne, known not only for his pride but his fierce fighting against the Saracens.
non vaut si is written over a scratch-out.
The bone is very hard to read because of a black smear at the top of the folio that almost completely covers it.
The original could have read "por voir et por semblant"; cf. 2912, 3930, etc. ("por voir") and 2450, 10258, etc., ("por semblant"), something like "truly and seemingly"

s'apaser: for OF "s'apaisier," 'se reconcilier'. One wonders if this should be emended to s'aparler: he began to discuss/talk with those whom he met. This section is difficult to understand (though clear to read) through the next line. T also is problematic, so the archetype must have been so.
po[est]és: cf. forms of "e[st]" and four other forms of poeste(s). T: per fare a luy dalmazo, si aveseno posanza, v. 9959.
Scattolini picks up her transcription again here.
Cf. Inf. 8.43-45, where Virgil embraces and kisses Dante for reacting strongly to Filippo Argenti. While Dante does not show Virgil laughing, strong positive emotion is present in both.

Tisiaus: Tisias is reported to have been the first theoretician of rhetoric in ancient Greece. It is taken that he was the student of one Corax, who has left no written work. Tradition has it that, after the fall of the monarchy in Sicily in the 5th c. BCE, the rise of democracy occasioned a need for persuasive speech (command no longer being accepted). One successful Sicilian practitioner was Gorgias who went to Athens in 427 BCE, where he became a major figure among the Sophists. In the Gorgias, Plato accused rhetoricians of favoring opinion over truth, success in the moment over enduring verities. (See also Phaedrus 267a-b.) Thus, in the history of rhetoric, Tisias would stand in the same relationship to rhetoric as the Sophists to sophistry. Support for this view comes in the theory that Corax was not a separate person, but that the word, which means "crow" is actually a derogatory nickname for Tisias himself. Rhetoric received a higher standing with Aristotle, fascinated with how things break down into their component parts, who wrote his Rhetoric as an analytical guide to, and practical manual for, the art—but he distinguished it from logic (dialectic). In the later Middle Ages, therefore, Tisias may be taken as a mythical founder, an archetype for all who indulge in untruth for emotional effect. Whatever his reputation in antiquity, in this passage, Berlin, lines 10324-10351, Tisias seems to represent all seven liberal arts (10328). The reference to his singing includes another of the seven: grammar, logic, rhetoric, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music. Wilfred Major, Epicharmus, Tisias, and the Early History of Rhetoric, Harvard Studies in Classical Philology 107 (2013), 55-72; A. G. Hinks, "Tisias and Corax and the Invention of Rhetoric," The Classical Quarterly 34,1/2 (Jan.-Apr., 1940), 61-69. (Alan E. Bernstein).
Scattolini: canter la usance

This scene may refer to the beginning of the mass; at that era, the "introit involves the singing of a Psalm, which by this period would have been sung alternatingly by two choir bodies." It may be like improvisory practice where "one singer or group of singers would sing the original chant tune, and the other voices might improvise or sing composed counterpoint above it" and "vocal polyphony was used during mass, often with a low line carrying the chant tune, and upper voices providing countermelodies, improvised or otherwise." Where and when it was done and if the celebrant was involved would be difficult to verify since the specific origin of this story is not known. We thank Remi Chiu (Fine Arts (Music), LUM) his collaboration. We also thank Francesca Gambino (U. of Padova) who pointed out that "abis" as an adverb could reflect the verb "abesse" ("abaisser") in line 10333, "low(er)." "bis" in its modern sense first appears in the nineteenth century according to DEAF.
Scattolini: biscant
There appears to have been a saut de même au même in an original text here, since both B and T repeat the same verb in two lines in a row. The second would be more likely "dit"/"dist" or "fait."
El = et + il
Scure appears twice in the text; obscure or oscure in various forms, seven times. There are no forms with an a- prefix.
Scattolini: maint [et] en

The identity of these devils is not positive, but Dante's Flegias appears in Inf. 8; Classical Phlegyas tried to burn down Apollo's temple at Delphi and thus Apollo condemned him to suffer in the afterlife; Ajax committed suicide in shame; Brugier we are not sure about at this time.
ras: Turin has "rasy", shorn, but in OF "ras" can also mean "guilty." That (guilt) however would not be immediately visible to the bystander.
The construction of this line is somewhat unclear: croie is clear in the MS; in T the line is also problematic. Cf. line 420, cro ge.
Scattolini ends a quote here, but the beginning is not clear.
hoeç is written over a scratch out.
End of Scattolini's transcription.

Illumination at the bottom of 72R illustrates this scene; at the left the three travellers through Hell, Huon, St. William and Aeneas, led by Huon. To the right, naked figures are lifted by a devil with fire around (v. 10396); below, in a pool of blue, other naked figures with a dragon and little fires. Above the devil at top in middle, the initial 'R' in white on the blue upper portion, for Roger (v. 10401).
Cf. the devils in pitch of Inf. 21-22, esp. 22.131, 'falcon [...]'
stoit appears 37 times; and only one other time might there be istoit, line 2684 (see note at that line). Thus we interpret here as "qui stoit". Cf. Turin 10054,"Ora me conta ch'è stà lo tuo pecato"
See Meregazzi, p. 34.
MS: toe. This is oddly formed- looks like 'tor' since final letter partially behind second.

This is the subject of the illumination at the bottom of 72V. To the left are our three travelling figures, with Aeneas at the front this time; in the middle is a king on horseback, with gold crown and leggings, completely covered with armor and decorations; his horse is also covered with a blue cloth decorated with two lions rampant. The king holds a lance inclined up. To the right are two naked figures with bloody holes.
A spot on the MS here is over the last letter; it looks like a round candle wax spot scraped off (it does not go through the folio).

The Roman d'Alexandre (Alexander Romance) is quite important in Huon for its voyages into the East and for its moral commentary. Alexandre tried to rule the world and the air and seas, which was frequently construed as overreaching. For a summary of the story and information about the various versions, the basic reference work is George Cary, The Medieval Alexander (Cambridge UP, 1956; rpt. 1967). A more recent compendium is David Zuwiyya's A Companion to Alexander Literature in the Middle Ages (Brill, 2011). For specific influences, see Meregazzi (1937); for further bibliography, see Morgan (2015).
fou: for Old French fo (T-L 'beech-wood')
VV. 10501-10103 reproduced and translated in Vidossi (Origini pp. 1214-1215), without capitals except at the beginning of sentences.
Note the assonance in this laisse, as opposed to rhyme generally found.

estandre: Holtus in Aliscans defines "estandre" as Italian “estendere," which means 'to extend, stretch,' and in his Lexicalische (p. 278) equates it with "destendre," meaning 'to kill' among other things.

alâ vendre: "alla a vendre": in Italian, "andare" is constructed with the preposition before an infinitive. It is not clear whether or not that preposition would be present here. The few forms followed by an infinitive are split between its presence and its absence, and a number are like this case here, where the infinitive also starts with an "a."
This is not, of course, the Chanson de Roland's fate for Ganelon, where he is torn apart by horses only. There, it is his thirty oath-swearers who are hanged.
This statement fits with the Dantean configuration of hell, where Lucifer and other traitors are at the deepest point, furthest from heaven.

The MS hand is slightly different here: abbreviation lines are shorter, writing tighter through the end of this column. Last reference to Aeneas is in this line. Vidossi and Aresi reproduce and translate into Italian (Origini pp. 1214- 1218, even pages).

This is the scene of the illumination at the bottom of 73. Three men to the left, led this time by St. Guillaume, with Aeneas standing to the back, in front of a hairy devil on a bench. The devil is in chains crossed across his chest and holding his legs together; he holds a crown in his right hand and a ring in his left. There are other similar devils behind him holding spears and pastoral cruxes (like the papal one).

Vidossi: l'en feise "se così facessi, molti agirei malamente" = 'if I did that, I would act very badly.' But this is not supported by the MS reading because of the verb ending. The line could be emended to "ovrerais" for raise syllable count to 6+6 (cf. line 2218).
Note that this is the one of the three gifts comprising the tribute that is not illustrated in the illumination on 73R.

ferais: Mainone (Formen, p. 14, p. 27), lists this as an example of a first-person singular future with the ending formed by analogy with second-person endings (his line count follows that of Stengel, off by 157 lines as an allowance for the missing siege of Auvergne). Yet in the following paragraph on p. 14 he also says that the future for the second-person singular is often in -ais. All six appearances of ferais here in B are second-person singular. Turin 10248 instead understands as "I will never do such an order (command)," "No[n] farazo my," dize lo [con]te, "tal comandame[n]to", and the "my" [MSI 'mica'] is perhaps what led Mainone astray.
End of Vidossi and Arese's transcription and translation.
MS: paus: not attested in other Franco-Italian texts in this collocation. T reads "pasy", 'passes'. We emend to "païs"; perhaps a saut de même au même, seeing crueus afterward.
la ci: this is an unusual construction, appearing nowhere else in the MS. It would seem to be direct object (referring to food) plus adverbial "there."
There is no abbreviation in the MS.

faigé : this may be a lenited form of "fatigué": intervocalic t>d>ø. It is not found in RIALFrI (14.IV.19). Cf. lines 1965, 11142, faigeç (equivalents in T: fadigà; afinato [afiné = "épuisé," Matsumura]).
The first part of illumination, 74R, bottom: hairy devil carrying Huon at table through the air. He's sleeping on the table, with various things on the table.
End of Stengel's "Hollen...," v. 10827.
Begin Stengel's "Karl Martel's Enführung," his v. 10828.

quasa: the word in this particular form does not seem to appear in other Franco-Italian texts or in commentary about Huon. It appears to be a variant spelling of "casser," here in the reflexive form. Matsumura documents both the abstract sense (WatrS, quasse) and the reflexive, but not together (as does T-L). Other appearances in Franco-Italian, while spelled with the same initial form, generally refer to physical combat (RIALFrI). T-L: REW quassare.However, there is a typical Franco-Italian verb that is reflexive: squassare, "to shake up, to shake violently"; cf. Aquilon de Bavière, vol. 3, p. 321, and entries in RIALFrI for "squaserent" (all "soi" or "se squaserent").
This section is somewhat comic, showing Huon as a naïf, not unlike Charlemagne in the Geste Francor, who marvels that someone (in his case, an angel) managed to get into the royal tent.
Stengel emends to [tres]tot; he emends to relate to Rajna's transcription of T. It would increase the syllable count to 12.

fron: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 331). In F-I, fron is feminine, under influence of Ital. "fronte." This and the one in v. 8886 are the only examples of six appearances where it might construed as feminine.

In the second part of the illumination below, Huon is inside a house by a window with grey outside, and his head is still on table, sleeping. Food items are on the table, including a partially-full glass, a flask of liquid, rolls and various containers.
A fold in the MS runs through these three lines, across "moiller," "encontrer," "Nul"

MS: sa moitist. There is no lexical item like this elsewhere in this text. The closest possibility in OF dictionaries seems to be "amoistir," to dampen, thus our word division. Looking elsewhere in the text we find "moit" (v. 7121) from "to move"; Matsumura lists "amovoir" but not reflexive form; T-L lists a possibly reflexive "movoir." If this were the case, it would signify "to gesticulate" as the text suggests already when he begs for pardon (v. 10730). The following tears and frequent expressions elsewhere about his dampening himself with tears make that seem more attractive as a possibility. We thank our consultants for their suggestions here.
The "que" or other conjunction seems to be missing here; cf. T 10413, "el no[n] pare ch'el sapia parlare [...]"

MS: aspë; T 10417: aspeto. There is no form "asper" or "aspre" as a noun; however, see l. 9352, sper, so we are interpreting this as a form of "esper" (cf. TL "esperer," "esperance"; Matsumura "espoire, espere" fem., F-I, "esperance" Entrée).
Cf. l. 1591, when Huon recalls knowing Sanson's father at Carcassonne.
Stengel: Or(e), to reduce syllable count to 12.
Stengel: [au]tresi

This is a problematic line; ator; DEAF "condition, état"; T-L: Stand, Zustand; Matsumura: condition; caractère; équipement; entourage; parure. Cf. line 12049. The meaning here is unclear, as is the word division; the MS reads a separation "la tor"; T 10446 reads similarly, "la tore." Since final consonants are frequently lost, here it may be equivalent to "la torne," defined in Matsumura "dédommagement," 'compensation'. Again, we thank our consultants for assisting with this line.
Stengel: Qu(ant)' a

Stengel: Ce (n)est [de] l'enfer che je ay che[rché] segnor (based on T); che can also signify "ce" and since with it the line is 10 syllables, should be considered as a possibility. It could also be missing a final consonant: cher = "that I hold dear." Stengel seems to have the right idea for the second hemistich (there are three forms of "che[r]re" in our text for "to seek") but removing an "n" as in the first hemistich is unusual. Rather than understanding the initial hemistich as modern French "ce n'est," if it is understood as one word, it can be a form of "cener/cignier" (there are three conjugated forms of "cigner" and four of "segné(s)"), "to signal, make a sign."
Stengel: Conseler [vos] devéç
Stengel: [nul] autre
See lines 8975 and 10944.
Stengel: (le) respont
Stengel: Parler [ge] voil
MS: se smoue. Forms of smou appear 4 times, esmou 3 times. Since the two are separated in the MS and there is no overwhelming evidence either way, we print here in two words.
Stengel: qui (qu')
Stengel: "[que] soit ...

Stengel: [e]n avray
Stengel: De [ce] qu'il dit non [le] croit il nïent
This line is a bit confusing, and T does not help; it seems to be "that you come out underneath" literally; the same is true for T 10571.
Stengel: Cuides [tu]
Stengel: Va [tost]
(i) above the line with caret below.

This is the scene illustrated in the illumination of 75V: At Charles's court (from left to right), the devil in the form of a pilgrim and Huon (with a red beard and lots of hair) extend a red cloth with golden birds on it. The king sits on a dais, crowned under a backdrop of white with red at the top. Several armed soldiers are at the far right beside the throne.
Stengel: Nus ni p[o]oit; see lines 8975 and 10819 for afaitement.
Stengel concludes this line with (!?)
Again a spot at the end of this line, circular perhaps originally a drop of wax now removed?
Stengel: [Si] tost

This is the scene of the illumination here on 76R: At Charles Martel's court still with Huon in bourgeois clothes to the left with some soldiers, to the right other soldiers with another bourgeois, and in the middle above Charles Martel on the red cloth decorated with gold birds, held up by haïry devils some red and some blue-gray. Crown is the same as in previous illumination, and the ring is not in presence either.
sorjugie seems to be a scribal error for "forjugie"; cf. line 8212.

Stengel ("Entführung"): (en)ça, le autre (en) la

Perhaps to be emended to "Jusqu'un anç"?
Stengel ("Entführung") : Iloch (il) sera
MS: redue. Cf. duire (TL), and Ital ridurre, past participle ridotto

en region: This line is quite different in T 10695, ch'el aza fama nel tenire razone "that he is reputed to be a good speaker." Here, the line seems to be negative in format, that he isn't married and that he isn't something else. One wonders if a "p" is missing, for "pregion" – 'in prison'– though that is not a form that appears in this text. Another possibility might be 'insane, unreasoned' for in+ rage + the rhyme syllable. (Cf. "ragne" v. 6450 for "regne"; ragine v. 3819 vs. "regn(e)" and "regine").
As usual, the "or" is written above the roman numeral.
Initial 'D' of this line the reverse of spot mentioned on 76R. The left side of the a is scraped or light. It would appear to be candle wax: the parchment page is thin and one can see through.

MS: laë, the two vowels are written as a ligature sharing the right side of the a and the left side of the e; it seems to be a correction. Since the reference is to a choice, a process-- ovrement–we write le.
Stengel: s'[il] avront feit

This folio, though a verso, is highly decorated; with the laisse "Segnor, seeç en pais..." it is like the beginning of a new chanson de geste, with a large and gilded capital, along with marginal color in red, green, blue, and gold.

There is an 'x' marked between this verse and the next in the right margin.

balaor: listed by Holtus under bailir, "donner," bailior, "conducteur" (Lexicalische, 227-28), but see Guerra d'Attila, "baleor: palco, balcone" and Entrée d'Espagne, "baucons: balcone". T reads "baladore" in lines 10886, 10887.

See note for line 1643.
s'arequoy: from "recoillir, recueillir" (Matsumura) as a reflexive form, with the prefix a-, frequent in Franco-Italian

The -en- of Veneç is in a circular brown spot, which does not seem to be wax (it does not go through the parchment). This section is illustrated in the illumination here on 78V: to the left are Huon in his recognizable yellow outfit, together with a group of men; in the center is a raised platform made of wood (with balustrade around above like the supports below), with two scenes also. In the first, the archbishop (distinguished by his red robes and typical white ... hat with a red cross) crowns the king (William), who is bearded and long-haïred; in the second, to the right, William marries Belisor—they are holding hands and she is accompanied by other women. Below the raised platform, on the right, are other men, two bearded, two not.

Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 227-28) gives baleor here and in v. 11238 as related to "bailior," "conducteur," or 'administrator' (T-L), related to the English 'baillif'. This is possible here, though the T 11006 "baladore" seems to suggest "ballatoio," a type of balcony, and the illumination suggests that.
Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): tot[e] celle
empois: we are presuming this is from "empeser"; cf. Godefroy's and Matsumura's citation of Anticlaudianus, defined, "appuyer fortement." It appears as one word in the MS.
Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): oit (a) non
End Stengel, "Karl Martel's Entführung", v. 11534. Begin Stengel's "Schluss", v. 11535.
Stengel ("Roms," p. 267): Por
scorceront: scorcher, Entrée d'Espagne: "écorcher", 'to skin alive'
Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): esillé. But cf. the preceding line: [...] asige, [...] prendront, where there are both a singular and plural verb.
Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): fuiç ont
gardenaus: cf. Holtus (Lexicalische, pp. 335-36), "cardinal."

The form adesie here is problematic. In Italian,"adire" means specifically "to go to [legal means], to sue"; thus this seems to imply some legal application. It could be "desirer" with the added prefix "a." adeser: to touch, reach, approach. In any case, the meaning seems to be something about what the ambassadors wish.
This is not the usual sight rhyme.

pogie: this is a hapax legomenon in this text. The second hemistich here makes little sense– the king placing a letter on his head (sor cef pogie) would not seem logical. A missing abbreviation line (for the final word) and/or erroneous readings-- of "s" for "f"– or a missing abbreviation– might be likely. The Turin line cannot however reflect what is here; *soi cef 'his leaders' or *pognie 'held in his fist' exclude each other. We propose emending the final -r of sor to i: "he offered it to his leaders."
Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): –E[n]segne est de bone compagnie–
Stengel ("Roms," p. 269) notes, "e ly" (the reading of T line 11073) for ol

As Stengel ("Roms," p. 269 n3) notes, 11462-11463 should go here, not where they appear: their rhyme would be appropriate to that previous laisse, and the sense fits as well. We have therefore placed them here.

This line and the next are out in the margin in line with the capital below (after line 11463 by this numbering). To the left is a large parenthesis around the two with a cross in the margin to the left of it. They clearly do not rhyme with the following laisse, by which they are written; Stengel notes that they should instead go with this laisse (with which they do rhyme), rather than the following.
oit could be either from "to have" or from "to hear"; since this is rhyme position, there is no dieresis, whichever meaning it holds. Turin uses a form of "to hear."
See note for line 11439, above.
-ç of sanç was changed from 't'.

Stengel ("Roms," p. 270): Ançois

The only full forms of this name are Willame, but there are two similar appearances of Guilla[u]me. We resolve the abbreviation W'ill'ame here like those.
despacer: cf. 8091, despaiç (cf. Wünderli, Aquilon, vol. 3, p. 268). The beginning of the quote is unclear; it could possibly begin with this line and follow to the next.
Stengel: contralïent, which would take the line to 12 syllables.
Stengel ("Roms," p. 272): en promis

deruer in OF is listed as transitive (Matsumura; T-L), and is transitive in the Guerra d'Attila; however, DELI lists the Italian reflex form (deriving from the same etymon) dirupare (first attested in Boccaccio, ca. 1336), as intransitive, and through lenition this could be the form here.
ên = "et en"
MS, Stengel ("Roms," p. 273): lay; MS: lay
D(i)ex: the i above the line (with no caret below) was clearly intended, but same ink and nib.

The illumination at the bottom of 80R relates to the fighting in the streets of Rome. The entire scene is within city walls, with a siege engine off to the extreme left (evident by its wood supporting structure in contrast to the continuous city walls). In the center is a religious figure in clerical garb giving a blessing with his right hand raised, two fingers out; he faces his right (our left). There are no recognizable figures in the fighting, all are in Western armor garb, with faces / necks covered (so no beards evident) and in armor, with no distinguishable armor covers. Some horses are also present.

MS: mërent. The two dots normally stand for an r plus a vowel, but here an r is already present. Turin l. 11222: Allor de speto li metono, followed by a description of broken trunks and clothes thrown out. Stengel: merrent

The illumination at the bottom of 81V shows the battle outside the city, with the city walls to the left and two groups confronting each other on horseback. On the center left, there is a brown horse with a red cover, gold lions on it; to the right is a white horse with a green blanket covered with a flowered design. Above this, a man's head (with reddish-brown beard) is upside-down, presumably cut off. It is interesting that though foot-soldiers and archers are mentioned with each group none are illustrated.
Stengel ("Roms" p. 278): gard(e)

Stengel ("Roms," p. 279): Ugon [li] ançoner

ançoner:while the meaning to the term seems clear, locating a specific origin is difficult. In the Geste Francor one finds "ançioner," which Mussafia, in the phrase "non sia ançoner" interprets "non sia tenuto in onore" [not held in honor], deriving it from ancien, so literally here, "the most senior." Another alternative is that it might be derived from "ancone" : in T-L this is a banner with the Virgin Mary on it ( from Greek eikon); ançoner would be the banner-carrier, the leader (cf. Matsumura, "ancoine"). Or finally, it could derive from ainçois, ançois for "first," here with a suffix, so the first, the leader (ainz takes numerous combinations and -er is a typical Franco-Italian suffix, particularly for a person; cf. Holtus, Lexicalische p. 99, p. 115).
host âsauter= "host a asauter"

The illumination at the bottom of this 82V shows the confrontation of the pope. The pope is in red in the middle, with his right hand raised. He is on a throne. To his right (viewer's left) is a very short king in a crown dressed in blue, with his arms crossed and men behind him, swords drawn. To the right (pope's left) are other men, also with swords, the second one with his half-way out of the sheath.

Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): jons. Holtus (Lexicalische, p. 355), gives this as a form of "joindre" meaning "venir," 'to come,' that appears in Franco-Italian. T gives "zonse", "to join" (cf. MSI 'giunse'). However, with two syllables (as in i ons) the line is a decasyllable, and i appears frequently as 'there' in this text. There is no connection between the i and the o: compare ior and several other combinations in the column to the left.

firant: according to Mainone (Formen, p. 27), this is a perfect form of the verb "faire." It is the only form of "faire" in the text with an -ant ending, but is also in rhyme. There are 28 appearances of firent. It would seem, however. that since this is an event in the future, it might be an analogical (and rhyme) form of the future or a conditional, which have other endings with an a.

The illumination here on 83V is the ordalie, the judicial combat: inside a palisade, two groups are fighting. To the left is the pope with two other clerics, one in white and one in red. To the right is a stylized tree (outside the palisade enclosure).

stange: cf. DELI "stanga," 'long, wooden pole' used for the two sides of a cart to place horses, or to divide stalls in a barn (med. Lat in Bologna, 1253; Boccaccio 1348-53), Geste Francor, poles used to hit others.
This is the hair side of the parchment and in this section, the pores are visible and make reading more difficult.

The illumination at the bottom of 84R shows the end of the combat: in the same palisade, the pope and various other men (not the clerks in 83V) are in the middle, with one armed man lying to the left and one to the right, on piles of armor/men. To the viewer's left is a man in a red surcoat with a golden lion; his eyes are closed. To the viewer's right lies a man with a yellow surcoat over his armor; it has black imperial eagles on it. His eyes are open.

It is unclear whom the poet might have in mind for reconquering the Empire from the Germans in 100 years (Turin gives 400 years). Giovanni Villani's Nuova Cronica (ed. by Giuseppe Porta [ Parma: Fondazione Pietro Bembo / Ugo Guanda, 1991]; e-text downloaded 10 June 2018, https://www.liberliber.it/mediateca/libri/v/villani/nuova_cronica/pdf/nuova__p.pdf) which dates to the beginning of the fourteenth century, mentions various rulers named "Carlo Martello," and it is a recurring name in the Anjou family. The Cronica notes that Charlemagne's family ceased ruling at the time of Ugo Ciapetta, Duca d'Orliensa. It tells of a Carlo Martello in the 1280's (pp. 200 ff), who, by his actions in the southern portion of the Italian peninsula and Sicily, seems to refer to the Charles Martel who lived 1271-95. The Anjou family in the peninsula in any case was very important, so either this reference or that of Turin may be linked to the French royal family in the peninsula at the time of the poem.
